bibl.title: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Robert M. O'Reilly, July 21, 1908

div1.p: Gorgas writes to O'Reilly concerning the administrative reorganizations in the Panama Canal Zone. He offers a political analysis of the situation.

div1.head: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Robert M. O'Reilly, July 21, 1908

opener.dateline:
DEPARTMENT OF SANITATION
Ancon, Canal Zone,
July 21st, 1908.

div1.p:
I have had my talk with Goethals and everything has been settled amicably
between us. McCulloch's cable was due to a radical reorganization which Goethals had
ordered. Two days after giving order he revoked it. He tells me that he does not
intend to give any orders to the Sanitary Department. That what he says is sugges-
tive and that if I act upon it, I assume the entire responsibility. His entire at-
titude has changed to me and we are now on more friendly terms than at any time in the
past. He denies flatly to me that he has ever made any criticism of my administra-
tive ability or the administration of my department and says that he does not think
any criticism is sustained by the conditions. The whole conversation was a complete
change of attitude and I think some time you would be interested in the details.
If Goethals stands to what he says my position will be much stronger than it has ever
been since I have been on the Isthmus and I am more than satisfied.

I hear that one of my principal assistants saw a cable to Goethals signed by
the President, telling him not to make changes in the Sanitary Department. I expect
to see this man in a day or two and find out more about it. The cable was said to
have been received on the 4th. I saw the President on the 8th.

What has occurred I think is this: When Taft was here Goethals proposed a
radical reorganization for the whole work. Taft agreed to all except Blackburn's
department. This department was not touched. When Taft got back to Washington he
submitted the matter to the President. The President kicked. I know he wanted to
keep Jackson Smith. Taft finally persuaded him to yield on everything except the
Sanitary Department. That the President cabled with regard to the Sanitary Depart-
ment and Goethals revoked his orders. If this is the case I will not stand much show
after Roosevelt goes out.

Goethals has completely reorganized everything on the Isthmus except the
Blackburn's and my department, and everything is in a ferment. This reorganization
in general seems to me good. But he has done it without gloves. I think I could
have put on a pair of gloves and done it without creating the row that he has.
Please remember me most cordially to Mrs. O'Reilly.
Phillips and Lyster are both working themselves thin over their examination.
